The essay also mentions that Adobe is a global company with an expectation that the majority of its revenue comes from outside the United States. Additionally, the essay states that Adobe's overall effectiveness can be maximized only when its employees come together as a cohesive unit. Finally, the essay mentions that Adobe's financial performance has weakened in recent quarters, but the company aims to correct its course while maintaining its cultural heritage.

Adobe's ability to perform well as an organization is affected by several specific activities and business characteristics. Adobe was founded on a set of core values and beliefs [1]. The raw materials from which Adobe's business is formed are the inventive ideas and creative talent of its employees [2]. Adobe's strong financial balance sheet is not based on assets such as factories, warehouses, storefronts, or mining and mineral rights, but on its people who are skilled in sales, marketing, engineering, and administration [3] [4]. Therefore, the way Adobe behaves and operates its culture directly affects the financial success of its business [5]. Meetings are an important part of Adobe's culture, and they should be convened only when written communication cannot effectively convey the required information or when the opportunity to provide a forum for interactive communication and discussion of ideas is the primary purpose of the meeting [6]. Conveners should consider the hidden costs of face-to-face meetings, including travel expenses, absence of the traveling participants from their local offices, and the negative impact on the quality of home and family life that result from extensive travel [7] [8]. Effective control of spending requires constant vigilance, and each employee has a role to play in controlling Adobe's costs [9] [10]. A successful business organization must operate as a team, not as a loosely knit federation of individuals, and a successful manager must first be a leader who focuses primarily on leading and not directing [11] [12] [13]. The global nature of Adobe's business places an even higher premium on effective horizontal communication throughout the organization [14]. The most important virtue of Adobe's corporate culture is honesty, and the only sure-fire way to be asked to leave this organization is to knowingly fail to tell the truth [15] [16]. To maintain the important components of Adobe's culture, the company must commit to excellent, predictable financial performance [17]. Finally, Chuck Geschke, Adobe's co-founder, instilled a relentless drive for innovation in the company, resulting in some of the most transformative software inventions, including the ubiquitous PDF, Acrobat, Illustrator, Premiere Pro, and Photoshop. As much as his inventions changed the world, it is his focus on people, purpose, and culture that has profoundly impacted each of us at Adobe [18] [19] [20] [21].
